title: ‘Cruel to Be Kind’ Review: In the Right Measure
text:
Chrissie Hynde calls the English bassist, songwriter and producer Nick Lowe “one of the greats,” and Huey Lewis calls him “a treasure.” Mr. Lowe’s songs have been recorded by Johnny Cash (“The Beast In Me”), Diana Ross (“I Live on a Battlefield”) and Elvis Costello (“(What’s So Funny ’Bout) Peace, Love and Understanding”). In the 1970s, Mr. Lowe played bass in the ill-fated New Wave group Rockpile, pioneered the independent record label as the in-house producer at Stiff Records, and had solo hits with “Cruel to Be Kind” and “I Love the Sound Of Breaking Glass.” Later, musicians of the caliber of John Hiatt and Ry Cooder sought out “the Jesus of Cool.” Yet Nick Lowe, Will Birch writes in this entertaining biography, remains “a cult-throb, singing only to the choir and maybe a couple of stragglers in the churchyard.”

Born in 1949, Mr. Lowe was the son of a decorated RAF pilot and his musical wife. “Nickie” grew up on bases in Germany and the Middle East, where he entertained his parents’ friends on the ukulele. After boarding school in England, the 16-year-old Lowe joined a guitarist schoolfriend, Brinsley Schwarz, in a band called Kippington Lodge, a name right out of “Spinal Tap.” By the end of the 1960s, the band, now called Brinsley Schwarz, were hippies playing what would now be called lo-fi Americana, but what sounded at the time like The Band with the amps turned down.

Cruel to Be Kind By Will Birch

Da Capo, 406 pages, $28

Brinsley Schwarz are now remembered only for what Mr. Birch calls “the sheer audacity” of their failed hype. In 1970 their manager flew a planeload of intoxicated British journalists to New York to witness the band’s American debut at the Fillmore East. The band, “shaken” after their long journey and stoned courtesy of their limo driver, played poorly, and the journalists were not so intoxicated as to miss the weak performance.

The early 1970s were a hard education for Mr. Lowe, living in a communal farm outside London as the band’s girlfriends tended the vegetable patch, catatonic on LSD while Brinsley Schwarz stagnated on the “pub rock” circuit. But this apprenticeship also taught Mr. Lowe the crafts of songwriting and production. In 1974, he wrote his first masterpiece, “Peace, Love and Understanding.” When pub rock mutated into punk and then New Wave, Mr. Lowe became the sympathetic older brother who knew how the business and the studio worked. He cultivated a blokey, jokey studio manner, oiled by a 50-50 bottle of vodka and orange, but he had a seasoned ear for a hook. The bands called him “Basher,” allegedly for his recording technique—“bash it down and tart it up later”—though Mr. Lowe insists in this account it was a send-up of his father’s RAF slang.

Mr. Lowe produced the first British punk single and album, the Damned’s thunderous “New Rose” (1976) and “Damned Damned Damned” (1977), as well as the Pretenders’ debut, “Stop Your Sobbing’” (1979). He produced two albums for Graham Parker and the Rumour, and five for Elvis Costello, including tracks like “Watching the Detectives” (1977), “Pump It Up” (1978) and “Oliver’s Army” (1979). Somehow, Mr. Lowe also made time to get on stage and onto the tour bus, partnering with Dave Edmunds, the Welsh Chuck Berry, in the mighty Rockpile. They were scorching live, but with Mr. Lowe contracted to Stiff, and Mr. Edmunds contracted to Led Zeppelin’s manager Peter Grant, Rockpile’s records had to be issued as Lowe or Edmunds solo albums.

Now married to Carlene Carter, the daughter of June Carter and stepdaughter of Johnny Cash, Mr. Lowe taught Huey Lewis, then in country band Clover, the rudiments of touring: “You put your toothbrush in your pocket, you put your skinny jeans on, and you buy a three-pack of clean underwear every three days. We meet in the bar at seven, we get in, we do our thing, we get out. And there’s no whining and no whingeing.” Wining, however, was compulsory. Mr. Lowe would “ski down mountains of cocaine into lakes of vodka” (in the parlance of the Rockpile and Costello roadshow), then come home to find Johnny Cash composing at the breakfast table and June Carter Cash wearing rubber gloves with her diamond rings on the outside. Neither Rockpile nor his marriage survived. Albums like “Nick the Knife” and “The Abominable Showman” did not live up to their punning titles.

In 1983, Mr. Lowe ended a five-year lost weekend: “Lose the booze and get yourself a new act,” he told himself. The cooler, older Lowe became a gangly English guest in the inner circle of country songwriting—in Ry Cooder’s estimation, a “real straight arrow-type of cat with a good mind upstairs and plenty on the ball.” Backing in and out of the spotlight with controlled English reticence, Mr. Lowe developed his studio patter into a bantering acoustic solo show.

Like Mr. Lowe, Will Birch is a pub-rock veteran and ex-producer. He is casually expert in the way of those rare music writers who can both play music and write, and his account of life on the road is brutally and comically frank. He likes his subject as a friend, but then, it’s hard not to like a legend who, hearing he’s been offered a spot at a jazz festival in west London, says, “Lovely . . . I can get there on the bus.”

Nick Lowe is one of the unusual artists whose songs are better known than he is. He was cruel to his fame in order to be kind to his talent.

—Mr. Green is Life & Arts editor of Spectator USA.
description: Nick Lowe produced Elvis Costello’s classics. Later, musicians like Ry Cooder sought out “the Jesus of Cool.”
